course.subject: MARK
course.name: Business to Business Marketing
course.description: The fundamental character of business markets and the decision-making nature of organizational customers; different approaches to business marketing, as typified in the relationships between buyers and sellers, and built around the concept of value; current trends changing the face of business-to-business marketing; critical analysis and problem-solving with respect to business market management.

reviews.author: H.W.
reviews.title: Friendly Professor but boring contents
reviews.comment_content:
- Broad introduction on B2B Marketing and a stimulation game - MikesBikes.
- Textbook: Business-to-Business Marketing, 5th Edition: Ross Brennan, Louise Canning, & Raymond McDowell
- He focuses on slides rather than the textbook. It is unnecessary but good for your understanding because sometimes he didn't clearly explain terms on the slides.

1. Introduction of B2B Markets & Marketing
2. Buyer Behavior
3. Inter-Firm Relationships & Networks
4. Responsible B2B Strategy
5. Researching B2B Markets
6. Business Market Segmentation
7. Market Communication
8. Relationship Communication
9. Relationship Portfolios & Key Acct. Mgmt.
10. Pricing for B2B Markets

- There were two guest speakers who were industry professionals.
- Gene told about MikesBikes strategies but I think it is more useful to read through the whole student manual by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gene is friendly and supportive; however, there's no much interaction or dynamic in the classes. He tends to skip some of the slides and provides a lot of personal experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
He tried to give everyone good grades. There were two round of stimulation and only counted whichever the shareholder value was higher (according to the ranking).

Grading Scheme:
Mid-Term: 30% - 82.5/99 (mean:73.5)
Final: 30% - 80/100 (mean 68.9)
MikesBikes: 30% (Mikesbikes shareholder value & Final report)
- Mikesbikes performance: 15/20 (mean: 16.8)
- Final report: 9.5/10 (mean 9.4)
Class Participation 8% - 8/8 (everyone has the same score)
Research Participation 2% - 2/2

Exams were T/F and multiple choices.

I knew my team would perform really bad in the stimulation so I studied hard on the exams in the hope of compensating the bad performance of the game. Still only got B+ for the final grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
The biggest workload would be the stimulation and it really depends on your teammates. So pick your teammates WISELY!! My group spent a lot of time for meetings (2-3 hours per time, 3 times a week), which was no efficient and spent a lot of time arguing. I heard some groups spent 30 min to 1 hour on average and still achieve great results.
The final report will be based on your thought and learning of the stimulation. It wouldn't take much time.

Quizzes were easy. You just have to focus on what he said (examples and videos during the lectures) instead of the slides and textbooks.

reviews.author: christygg
reviews.title: super good prof and good grade
reviews.comment_content:
- It is an elective mark course

- will apply many of the familiar marketing concepts and frameworks of such as segmentation, buying behavior, pricing and distribution strategies, demand generation, and customer relationships in a business context.   

- have the opportunity to apply principles directly via a business simulation game called Capstone, from Capsim. This game will be a key pillar of the course and will be conducted in groups. Itâ€™s a simulation that is specifically oriented to B2B and a perfect adjunct to the textbook and lecture material.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gene is a super nice prof, always make jokes during the class. He will ask everyone to bring name card so he will recognise and rmb your name (usually the student in the front row ;p)

-but sometimes will fall asleep since Gene will just read aloud the ppt (of coz he will give an additional example and explaining, still sometimes i get bored..)
reviews.comment_grading:
- 2 quizzes (socred >= 1sd) , i think is easy, just revise the lecture notes and if u miss the lecture, still have video to revise

- for the group work, i have to thank my teammates who carry a lot, thus score high marks (>1sd)

-no attendance check

-participation score (if you want a full mark, you need to sit in the front and always response him; otherwise just score the mean..... most students just score the mean, including me)

-marketing research 2 credit (so easy, just rmb to sign up)

=> turns out A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Individual:
- 2 quizzes (MCQ + T/F), close bk

Group: (no presentation!!!)
- one HKCEC visit (to understand how BTB runs) + one post-visit short report
- one simulation grp work "Capsim"!!! have 8 rounds= every week (whole semester need to skype/hv meeting) ---> super important !! have to find good teammates to work tgt + one post-game report

-i think for group work is a bit chur, coz you need to write a lot in the report (as comprehensive as much, Gene will be happy), while you always need to meet and discuss w/ grpmate on the simulation game (super time consuming, always skype meeting for 2-3 hrs)

reviews.author: avv
reviews.title: An alright course
reviews.comment_content:
This course is about B2B marketing focusing on business selling to other business rather than consumers from what we usually are familiar with.

The slides are all based on the textbook so there is no need to buy the textbook, contrary to what they say in class.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof. teaches fine and is quite nice, but sometimes his explanations may be a bit vague and not provide any deeper insight than the theory.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 quizzes: 20%, 20%, 25% respectively.
Participation: 13%
Trade show report: 15%
Research credit: 2%

Quizzes are all MCQs so you can imagine the mean is high. So literally just memorize the slides for the test and you would find it easy to do the exam.

Trade show report: you will be required to attend a trade show and choose a company that has displayed its product in the show and write a report focusing on the product and the company.

Lot of group activities in class where you'd need to fill out some BS answers in a worksheet and add your name and SID
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light.

Just do the report according to the guidelines.

This course is a chill elective for MARK majors, but don't expect to learn much.

reviews.author: neilomo
reviews.comment_content: This course focuses on B2B marketing, where the main content is about the methods or strategies that most companies would adapt in order to have a higher chance to get the orders from other companies. It is quite informative as there is a new powerpoint slide for almost each lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gene is a well-experienced expert in marketing industry. He often uses his own experience or real life examples during lectures so it's quite practical indeed. He is also a funny guy who always makes jokes during lecture (not many ppl are laughing tho).
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading with absolute good grade. Here is the grading scheme:
Current grading scheme for this assignment
A+: 100 % to 92.0%
A: < 92.0 % to 90.0%
B+: < 90.0 % to 88.0%
B: < 88.0 % to 86.0%
B-: < 86.0 % to 85.0%
C+: < 85.0 % to 80.0%
C: < 80.0 % to 60.0%
D: < 60.0 % to 50.0%
F: < 50.0 % to 0.0%

The professor is extremely kind when comes to grading. He is willing to give credits to questions which students think it is argumentative (basically he just want everyone to have good grade haha). The mean for the quizzes is around 87.
reviews.comment_workload: Least workload course in HKUST. All you need to do is 3 quizzes (30% each), participation (8% where everyone got at least 7%) and research credit (2%, compulsory for every marketing course).

reviews.author: gradehunter
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about B2B marketing. It introduces concepts, tools and technologies applicable to managers in industrial products, consulting services, institutional investing, technology products, business services and other categories where the customer is a business, versus a consumer.   To sell successfully to business buyers, you need particularly to understand whatâ€™s uniquely B2B in the areas of market segmentation, buying behavior, pricing and distribution strategies, demand generation, and customer relationship management.  

A lot real life examples will be taught in the course. There are a lot of powerpoints to read and they are all very informative. Textbook is not required. This course mainly assess students on their understanding and applications.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very knowledgeable. He has worked in several multinational corporations and is willing to share his experience. You can learn a lot of marketing knowledge and apply it in the marketing world. The professor replies to email very quickly.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was fair and within my expectation. It's absolutely graded which is good. I think his scale is pretty lenient
reviews.comment_workload: 3 exams, no project, no individual assignments. All exams are in term period. The workload is light if you don't like projects but you may need to study more than other marketing course, even though it's open book, concepts and understanding is tested more than hardcore knowledge.

reviews.author: chlkaren
reviews.title: Nice professor and easy content
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers the following topics:
1) B-to-B markets and Marketing
2) Buyer Behavior
3) Inter-Firm Relationships and Network
4) Responsible Business Strategy
5) Researching B-to-B Markets
6) Business Market Segmentation
7) Market Communication
8) Relationship Communication
9) Relationship Portfolios and Key Account Management
10) Managing Products for Business Markets

- Besides regular lectures, he arranged two guest speaker sections to share their experiences in B-to-B marketing.
(TIPS: some questions of the exam are related to the speakers' materials)

- Content of this course is slightly different from other mark courses, but Gene will provide a lot of examples to help you understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gene is funny and nice to students, he is happy to address all questions that you might have.
It is better for you to jot down the examples he mentioned in class because they are likely to be tested during midterm or final.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is as follows:
Mid-term: 30% (mean: 73.54)
Final Exam: 30% (mean: 68.63)
MikesBikes: 30%
Class Participation: 8%
Research Participation: 2%

The grading is quite good and your hard work will pay off!

I got highest for midterm and above mean for final; and one of the best-performing groups for MikesBikes. Full marks for class and research participation.

Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment but you need to complete a B2B Business Simulation Game â€“ MikesBikes.
Workload is a bit heavy because you would have to meet with your group every week to make decisions for this game.
Practice round is given, followed by 2 live rounds which you will be competing with your classmates from the same section.
You are also required to submit a reflection report about your performances of MikesBikes. This aims to help groups that did not perform well in live rounds to gain some extra credits.

reviews.author: therock
reviews.comment_content: Pretty boring content, easy to get distracted/tired in class
reviews.comment_teaching: Gene clearly wants the best for the class and tries to get us to participate, but (at least when class was online) it's pretty dead. He makes jokes and gives good examples-- in my opinion, one of the better profs in SBM, but depends on your style. Not all explanations are super clear.
reviews.comment_grading: Super good grading! Got above mean for midterm and final (SD not released), my team in the simulation game got 3rd place (out of 6 in our 'world'), and still A+ final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: For a 4 credit course, workload is pretty light. The thing that takes the most time would be the game, since your group has to meet pretty often to discuss actions for the next round. Other than that, you only need 2-3 days before midterm/final to study, and there's no presentation so pretty chill. However, since Gene cares about participation, you gotta attend lectures (I skipped maybe 5 in the semester and got full marks for participation, so on the ones you do attend make sure to speak up once and he'll remember you).
